oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:title: Ralph Emery Interviews Ronnie Milsap Parts 1, 2 and 3
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:description: Recording is from Ralph Emery's (entertainer) interview of Ronnie Milsap (performer) for Nashville's WSM. Tape labeled parts 1, 2 and 3. Recording is from an unknown date.
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:creator: Ralph Emery; Ronnie Milsap
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dcterms:tableOfContents: (00:00) Ralph Emery talks to an unknown voice away from the microphone -- (00:15) Ronnie Milsap and Ralph Emery address the audience and Emery performs his commercial break -- (00:39) Emery and Milsap discuss how Milsap will jog in less than ideal spots -- (03:53) Milsap recalls when he first heard "Don't You Know How Much I Love You" -- (05:15) Emery and Milsap discuss how Milsap plays the piano on a number of his recording sessions -- (07:03) Emery inquires about if Milsap was a daydreamer while introducing "Daydreams About Night Things" -- (09:02) Emery inquires about Milsap's impression of a duo of Ray Charles and Ricky Skaggs -- (09:43) Emery and Milsap discuss Milsap's health following an operation -- (14:31) Milsap discusses when he first started recording "Any Day Now" for Scepter -- (15:39) Emery confesses his confusion to why Milsap went into a session without a direction -- (16:17) Milsap and Emery discuss Milsap's difficulties with sight from an early age -- (19:17) Emery and Milsap perform their sign-offs -- (19:30) Emery performs his commercial breaks -- (20:13) Milsap and Emery discuss the times their show is performed -- (21:13) Ronnie Milsap and Ralph Emery address the audience and Emery performs his commercial break -- (21:57) Emery and Milsap discuss the studio location they are discussing in -- (22:45) Emery inquires about the controversy from "She Loves My Car," and Milsap discusses the culture the song targets -- (27:10) Emery Praises Milsap, and Milsap discusses the response he has had for "She Loves My Car" -- (28:05) Emery praises the work Milsap did on Kris Kristofferson's "Please Don't Tell Me How the Story Ends" -- (29:50) Emery and Milsap reflect on Tom Corley and Donald Reeves before Milsap tells a tale about a time with Stars For Children -- (36:22) Emery reflects on "Wrong Road Again" -- (36:47) Emery invites Milsap to reflect on the message of "There's No Getting Over Me" -- (38:32) Emery and Milsap say their sign-off and Milsap parodies a commercial break -- (39:08) Emery and Milsap converse away from the microphone -- (39:44) Milsap performs an introduction radio spot -- (39:55) Emery discusses the upcoming schedule to Milsap -- (40:19) Milsap performs an introduction radio spot -- (40:30) Emery discusses the upcoming schedule with Milsap -- (40:56) Emery introduces Milsap, performs his commercial break, and both comment on the commercial break -- (42:32) Emery and Milsap discuss how Eddie Rabbitt had introduced Milsap to "Pure Love" -- (43:57) Emery and Milsap discuss Milsap's first 'truck driving' song -- (46:20) Emery congrats Milsap on his nomination for Entertainer of the Year and both discuss the nominees -- (49:29) David Allen Coe's is addressed "It's Great to be Single Again" -- (49:50) "Still Losing You" is discussed by Milsap -- (51:37) Milsap mentions his fondness for the Whites -- (52:13) Emery inquires about what Milsap would have done if not music -- (56:20) Milsap recalls the time he spent touring with Exile -- (58:16) Emery and Milsap say goodbye to the audience
oai_qdc:qualifieddc.dc:subject: Milsap, Ronnie; Milsap, Ronnie, 1943-; Emery, Ralph;
